title: Getting Started with Next.js
description: A beginner's guide to building your first Next.js application

body.raw:
# Getting Started with Next.js Next.js has become one of the most popular frameworks for building React applications. In this post, I'll walk you through the basics of getting started with Next.js and building your first application. ## What is Next.js? Next.js is a React framework that provides a structure and features for your application, including: - Server-side rendering and static site generation - File-based routing - API routes - Image optimization - Font optimization - Built-in ESLint configuration It aims to provide the best developer experience with all the features you need for production. ## Setting Up Your First Next.js Project Let's start by creating a new Next.js project: ```bash npx create-next-app@latest my-first-nextjs-app cd my-first-nextjs-app ``` You'll be prompted to choose various options for your project. I recommend selecting TypeScript, ESLint, and Tailwind CSS for a modern development setup. ## Understanding the Project Structure After setup, you'll have a project with the following structure: ```text my-first-nextjs-app/ ├── app/ │ ├── page.tsx │ ├── layout.tsx │ └── globals.css ├── public/ ├── components/ ├── package.json └── next.config.mjs ``` The `app` directory contains your application code: - `page.tsx` - The main page component - `layout.tsx` - The root layout component - `globals.css` - Global styles ## Creating Your First Page Let's create a simple "About" page. With the App Router in Next.js, you can simply create a new directory with a page component: ```tsx // app/about/page.tsx export default function AboutPage() { return (

About Me

I'm a web developer passionate about building modern applications with Next.js and React.

); } ``` Now you can access this page at `/about`. ## Fetching Data Next.js makes data fetching simple. Here's an example of fetching data in a page component: ```tsx // app/posts/page.tsx async function getPosts() { const res = await fetch('https://jsonplaceholder.typicode.com/posts'); return res.json(); } export default async function PostsPage() { const posts = await getPosts(); return (

Posts

{posts.slice(0, 5).map((post) => (

{post.title}

{post.body}

))}
); } ``` ## Conclusion This is just the beginning of what you can do with Next.js. As you get more comfortable with the framework, you can explore more advanced features like API routes, middleware, and different rendering strategies. Next.js provides an excellent developer experience while enabling you to build performant applications. Whether you're building a blog, e-commerce site, or complex web application, Next.js has the tools you need to succeed.

title: Modern Web Development in 2023
description: An overview of the current state of web development and best practices

body.raw:
# Modern Web Development in 2023

The landscape of web development is constantly evolving, with new tools, frameworks, and best practices emerging regularly. In this post, I'll share my thoughts on the current state of web development and what I believe are the best approaches for building modern web applications.

## The Rise of Meta-Frameworks

One of the most significant developments in recent years has been the rise of meta-frameworks like Next.js, Remix, and Astro. These frameworks build upon existing libraries like React and provide additional features such as:

- Server-side rendering (SSR)
- Static site generation (SSG)
- Incremental static regeneration (ISR)
- API routes
- File-based routing

Next.js, in particular, has gained massive popularity due to its flexibility and excellent developer experience. It allows developers to choose the rendering method that best suits their needs for each page of their application.

## The Shift to TypeScript

TypeScript has become the standard for large-scale JavaScript applications. Its type system helps catch errors early in the development process and improves code maintainability. The benefits include:

- Better IDE support with autocompletion
- Easier refactoring
- Self-documenting code
- Fewer runtime errors

While there's a learning curve, the productivity gains from using TypeScript are significant, especially for larger projects and teams.

## CSS Evolution: Utility-First Approaches

Tailwind CSS has revolutionized how many developers approach styling. The utility-first methodology offers several advantages:

- Faster development without context switching
- Consistent design constraints
- No need to create and manage class names
- Reduced CSS bundle size

Combined with component libraries like shadcn/ui, developers can create beautiful, consistent interfaces without having to reinvent the wheel.

## Performance and Core Web Vitals

Google's Core Web Vitals have pushed performance to the forefront of web development priorities. Metrics like Largest Contentful Paint (LCP), First Input Delay (FID), and Cumulative Layout Shift (CLS) are now key considerations.

Next.js's image optimization, font loading strategies, and built-in performance features help developers achieve excellent performance scores without significant additional effort.

## Conclusion

The modern web development ecosystem continues to improve, with a focus on developer experience, performance, and maintainability. By embracing meta-frameworks, TypeScript, utility-first CSS, and performance best practices, developers can build better web applications more efficiently than ever before.

As we move forward, I expect to see further improvements in build tools, rendering strategies, and framework capabilities that will make web development even more powerful and accessible.
